{{short description|Population explosion of organisms that can severely lower oxygen levels in natural waters, killing marine life}} [[File:2008-08-22 White German Shepherd swimming in algae.jpg|thumb|A dog swimming through an algal bloom.]]
A '''harmful algal bloom''' ('''HAB''') are organisms that can severely lower oxygen levels in natural waters, killing marine life. Some HABs are associated with algae-produced toxins.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Eutrophication and harmful algal blooms: A scientific consensus|authors=J. Heisler, P.M. Glibert, J.M. Burkholder, D.M. Anderson, W. Cochlan, W.C. Dennison b, Q. Dortch, C.J. Gobler, C.A. Heil, E. Humphries, A. Lewitus, R. Magnien, H.G. Marshallm, K. Sellner, D.A. Stockwell, D.K. Stoecker, M. Suddleson|journal=Harmful Algae|volume=8|issue=1|year=2008|pages=3–13|doi=10.1016/j.hal.2008.08.006|pmid=28781587|pmc=5543702}}</ref> Blooms can last from a few days to many months. After the bloom dies, the microbes which decompose the dead algae use up even more of the oxygen, which can create [[fish die-off]]s. When these zones of depleted oxygen cover a large area for an extended period of time, they are referred to as [[Dead zone (ecology)|dead zones]], where neither fish nor plants are able to survive.
HABs are induced by an [[nutrient pollution|overabundance of nutrients]] in the water. The two most common nutrients are fixed nitrogen (nitrates, ammonia, urea) and phosphate.<ref name=CDC>[https://www.cdc.gov/habs/general.html Harmful Algal Blooms], ''Center for Disease Control''</ref> These nutrients are emitted by [[Agricultural pollution|agriculture]], other industries, excessive [[fertilizer]] use in urban/suburban areas and associated [[urban runoff]]. Higher water temperature and low circulation are contributing factors. HABs can cause significant harm to animals, the environment and economies. They have been increasing in size and frequency worldwide, a fact that many experts attribute to global climate change. The U.S. [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA) predicts more harmful blooms in the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Harvey |first=Chelsea |date=2016-09-29 |title=The Pacific blob caused an "unprecedented" toxic algal bloom — and there’s more to come |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/09/29/warm-oceans-caused-last-years-toxic-blob-and-more-algae-blooms-may-be-in-store |work=Washington Post}}</ref>
==Description and identification== [[File:Banter See 1348.jpg|thumb|px240|Algae on the coast of northern Germany]] HABs from [[cyanobacteria]] (blue-green algae) can appear as a foam, scum, or mat on or just below the surface of water and can take on various colors depending on their pigments.<ref name=CDC/> Cyanobacteria blooms in freshwater lakes or rivers may appear bright green, often with surface streaks which looks like floating paint.<ref name=California/> Similarly, red tides made up of dinoflagellates, also contain photosynthetic pigments that vary in color from green to brown to red.
Most blooms occur in warm waters that have excessive nutrients.<ref name="CDC"/> The harmful effects from such blooms is due to the toxins they produce or from using up oxygen in the water which can lead to fish die-offs.<ref name=usatoday>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/08/07/algae-blooms-economy-west-coast-toxic-bloom/31222581/ "What you need to know about toxic algae blooms"], ''USA Today'', August 7, 2015</ref>
Not all algal blooms are harmful, however, with some only discoloring water, producing a smelly odor, or adding a bad taste to the water. Unfortunately, it is not possible to tell if a bloom is harmful from just appearances, since sampling and microscopic examination is required.<ref name=CDC/>
==Types== [[File:Blue-gree algae bloom Lake Erie.png|thumb|px240|Cyanobacteria (blue-green algae) bloom on [[Lake Erie]] in 2009]] There are three main types of algae which can form into harmful algal blooms: [[cyanobacteria]], [[dinoflagellates]] and [[diatoms]]. All three are made up of microscopic floating organisms which, like plants, can create their own food from sunlight by means of [[photosynthesis]]. That ability makes them an essential part of the [[food web]] for small fish and other organisms.<ref name=Black>Black, Jacquelyn G., and Black, Laura J. ''Microbiology: Principles and Explorations'', 8th Ed., John Wiley & Sons (2012)</ref>{{rp|246}}
===Cyanobacteria=== Harmful algal blooms in freshwater lakes and rivers, or at [[estuaries]], where rivers flow into the ocean, are caused by cyanobacteria, also known as "blue-green algae".<ref name=Peebles>Peebles, Ernst B. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/the-conversation-us/why-toxic-algae-blooms-li_b_11082734.html "Why toxic algae blooms like Florida’s are so dangerous to people and wildlife"], ''Huffington Post'', July 20, 2016</ref> They can produce hazardous toxins, such as [[microcystins]],<ref name=NOAA/> a [[neurotoxin]] which destroys nerve tissue of mammals.<ref name=Utah/> In high enough concentrations, water treatment plants may be unable to remove the toxin and will advise residents to avoid drinking tap water, as happened in Toledo, Ohio in August 2014.<ref name=Toledo/>
They also cause harm by blocking the sunlight or by using up the oxygen needed by fish or plant life, which can lead to fish die-offs.<ref name="usatoday"/> When such oxygen-depleted water covers a large area for an extended period of time, it can become [[Hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxic]], commonly called a [[dead zone (ecology)|dead zone]]. These dead zones can be the result of numerous different factors ranging from natural phenomenon to deliberate human interaction. These dead zones are not just limited to large bodies of fresh water as found in the great lakes, but are also prone to bodies of salt water as well.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/deadzone.html|title='Dead zone' is a more common term for hypoxia, which refers to a reduced level of oxygen in the water|last=Administration|first=US Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric|website=oceanservice.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2017-10-22}}</ref>
===Red tides=== [[File:La-Jolla-Red-Tide.780.jpg|thumb|px240|A red tide off the coast of [[San Diego, California]]]] {{main|Red tide}}
The other types of algae are [[diatom]]s and [[dinoflagellate]]s, found primarily in marine environments, such as ocean coastlines or bays, where they can also form algal blooms, commonly called [[red tide]]s. Red tides, however, may be a natural phenomenon,<ref name=Red>[http://tpwd.texas.gov/landwater/water/environconcerns/hab/redtide/faq.phtml FAQs about red tides], Texas Parks & Wildlife Department</ref> although when they form close to coastlines or in estuaries. They can occur when warmer water, salinity, and nutrients reach certain levels, which then stimulates their growth.<ref name=Red/> Most red tide algae are dinoflagellates.<ref name=monterey>Ryan, John. [http://montereybay.noaa.gov/sac/2008/081508/081508ryan_ppt.pdf "Red Tide & HAB Studies in Monterey Bay"], Monterey Bay Sanctuary Advisory Council Meeting, August 15, 2008</ref> They are visible in water at a concentration of 1,000 algae cells per milliliter, while in dense blooms they can measure over 200,000 per milliliter.<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/09/150901144353.htm "Intense, widespread algal blooms reported in Chesapeake Bay"], ''Science Daily'', Sept. 1, 2015</ref>
Diatoms produce [[domoic acid]], another neurotoxin, which can cause seizures in higher vertebrates and birds as it concentrates up the food chain.<ref name=marine>[http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/science/top-research-projects/domoic-acid-toxicity.html "Domoic Acid Toxicity"], ''The Marine Mammal Center''</ref> Domoic acid readily accumulates in the bodies of [[shellfish]], [[sardines]], and [[anchovies]], which if then eaten by [[sea lions]], [[otters]], [[cetaceans]], birds or people, can affect the nervous system causing serious injury or death.<ref name=marine/> In the summer of 2015, the state governments closed important shellfish fisheries in [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Oregon]] and [[California]] because of high concentrations of domoic acid in shellfish.<ref name=shellfish>[https://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/news/features/west_coast_algal_bloom/index.cfm "NOAA Fisheries mobilizes to gauge unprecedented West Coast toxic algal bloom"], Northwest Fisheries Science Center, June 2015</ref>
==Causes== Among the causes of algal blooms are: * chemical wastes, primarily nutrients—[[phosphorus]] and [[nitrates]]—from fertilizers or human waste,<ref name="EPA-Climate">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/nutrientpollution/climate-change-and-harmful-algal-blooms |title=Climate Change and Harmful Algal Blooms |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2017-03-09 |website=Nutrient Pollution |publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref name=Peebles/><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Amin |first=Md Nurul |last2=Kroeze |first2=Carolien |last3=Strokal |first3=Maryna |date=2017 |title=Human waste: An underestimated source of nutrient pollution in coastal seas of Bangladesh, India and Pakistan |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0025326X17301595 |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=118 |issue=1-2 |pages=131–140 |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2017.02.045 |issn=0025-326X |via=}}</ref> * climate change with its resultant [[global warming]],<ref name="EPA-Climate"/><ref name=Florida/> * [[thermal pollution]] from power plants and factories, and * low water levels in inland waterways and lakes, which reduces water flow and increases water temperatures.<ref name=Utah>[http://kutv.com/news/local/neurotoxic-algae-bloom-shuts-down-utah-lake "Neurotoxic algae bloom that shuts down Utah Lake can affect brain, liver"], ''KUTV'', July 15, 2016</ref><ref name=Russian>[http://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/5741904-181/russian-river-to-be-closely?artslide=0 "Russian River to be closely monitored this summer to guard against harmful algae blooms"], ''Press Democrat'', June 23, 2016</ref>
Climate change, according to NOAA scientists, contributes to warmer waters which makes conditions more favorable for algae growth in more regions and farther north.<ref>[http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/algal-blooms-likely-to-flourish-as-temperatures-climb "Algal blooms 'likely to flourish as temperatures climb'"], ''Straits Times'', July 20, 2016</ref> Global warming is also considered a key factor for algal blooms in the Southern hemisphere, acknowledged by scientists in Australia.<ref>[http://www.sentinelsource.com/features/environment/the-disgusting-uptick-in-the-incidence-of-algae-blooms/article_147ea74e-d028-5191-88e9-c21d02bb7f95.html "The disgusting uptick in the incidence of algae blooms"], ''Washington Post'', August 1, 2016</ref> In general, still, warm, shallow water, combined with high-nutrient conditions in lakes or rivers, increases the risk of harmful algal blooms.<ref name=Russian/>
Nutrients enter freshwater or marine environments as [[surface runoff]] from [[agricultural pollution]] and [[urban runoff]] from fertilized lawns, golf courses and other landscaped properties; and from [[sewage treatment plants]] that lack nutrient control systems.<ref name="EPA-sources">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/nutrientpollution/sources-and-solutions |title=Sources and Solutions |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2017-03-10 |website=Nutrient Pollution |publisher=EPA}}</ref> Additional nutrients are introduced from atmospheric pollution.<ref name=Miller>Miller, G. Tyler Jr., ''Environmental Science'', Thomas Learning (2003) pp. 355{{endash}}357</ref> Coastal areas worldwide, especially wetlands and estuaries, coral reefs and swamps, are prone to being overloaded with those nutrients.<ref name=Miller/> Most of the large cities along the [[Mediterranean Sea]], for example, discharge all of their sewage into the sea untreated.<ref name=Miller/> The same is true for most coastal developing countries.
In the U.S., surface runoff is the largest source of nutrients added to rivers and lakes, but is mostly unregulated under the federal [[Clean Water Act]].<ref name="EPA 319 report">{{cite report |date=October 2016 |title=National Nonpoint Source Program: A catalyst for water quality improvements |url=https://www.epa.gov/nps/319-grant-reports-and-project-summaries |publisher=EPA |id=EPA 841-R-16-009}}</ref>{{rp|10}} <ref name="NPDES basic">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/npdes/npdes-permit-basics |title=NPDES Permit Basics |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2018-07-25 |website=National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System |publisher=EPA |quote=By law, agricultural stormwater discharges and return flows from irrigated agriculture are not 'point sources.'}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.circleofblue.org/2016/united-states/algal-blooms-no-accident-florida-everglades-estuaries/ |title=Algal Blooms Are No Accident For Florida Everglades and Estuaries |last=Kozacek |first=Code |date=2016-07-20 |website=Circle of Blue |location=Traverse City, Michigan}}</ref> Locally developed initiatives to reduce [[nutrient pollution]] are underway in various areas of the country, such as the [[Great Lakes]] region and the [[Chesapeake Bay]].<ref name="EPA-Great Lakes">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/glwqa |title=Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-08-29 |publisher=EPA}}</ref><ref name="EPA-Chesapeake TMDL">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/chesapeake-bay-tmdl |title=Chesapeake Bay Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2017-02-09 |publisher=EPA}}</ref> To help reduce algal blooms in [[Lake Erie]], the State of [[Ohio]] presented a plan in 2016 to reduce phosphorus runoff.<ref>[http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/05/26/states-plan-to-restore-lake-erie-stops-short-of-mandating-farming-changes.html# "Ohio plan to restore Lake Erie won’t mandate farming changes"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160801131937/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/05/26/states-plan-to-restore-lake-erie-stops-short-of-mandating-farming-changes.html |date=2016-08-01 }}, ''The Columbus Dispatch'', July 27, 2016</ref>
===Examples=== ====Texas==== Natural water reservoirs in [[Texas]] have been threatened by anthropogenic activities due to large petroleum refineries and oil wells (i.e. emission and wastewater discharge), massive agricultural activities (i.e. pesticide release) and mining extractions (i.e. toxic wastewater) as well as natural phe-nomena involving frequent HABs events. For the first time in 1985, the state of Texas documented the presence of the ''p. parvum'' (golden alga) bloom along the [[Pecos River]]. This phenomenon has affected 33 reservoirs in Texas along major river systems, including the Brazos, Canadian, Rio Grande, Colorado, and Red River, and has resulted in the death of more than 27 million fish and caused tens of millions of dollars in damage.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sharifan |first=Hamidreza |last2=Ma |first2=Xingmao |date=2017-08-31 |title=Potential Photochemical Interactions of UV Filter Molecules with Multichlorinated Structure of Prymnesins in Harmful Algal Bloom Events |url=http://www.eurekaselect.com/152553/article |journal=Mini-Reviews in Organic Chemistry |volume=14 |issue=5 |doi=10.2174/1570193x14666170518124658}}</ref>
====Chesapeake Bay==== [[File:July 12, 2013 - Sassafras River, VA Algal Bloom (9321804011).jpg|thumb|An algal bloom on the [[Sassafras River]], a tributary of the Chesapeake Bay]] The [[Chesapeake Bay]], the largest [[estuary]] in the U.S., has suffered from repeated large algal blooms for decades due to chemical runoff from multiple sources,<ref>[http://www.baltimoresun.com/health/bs-hs-algae-blooms-20150508-story.html "Scientists eye increase in harmful algae in Chesapeake"], ''The Baltimore Sun'', May 8, 2015</ref> including 9 large rivers and 141 smaller streams and creeks in parts of six states. In addition, the water is quite shallow and only 1% of the waste entering it gets flushed into the ocean.<ref name=Miller/>
By weight, 60% of the phosphates entering the bay in 2003 were from sewage treatment plants, while 60% of its nitrates came from fertilizer runoff, farm animal waste, and the atmosphere.<ref name=Miller/> About 300 million pounds (140 Gg) of nitrates are added to the bay each year.<ref>[http://www.cbf.org/about-the-bay/issues/dead-zones/nitrogen-phosphorus "Too Much Nitrogen and Phosphorus Are Bad for the Bay"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160728141032/http://www.cbf.org/about-the-bay/issues/dead-zones/nitrogen-phosphorus |date=2016-07-28 }}, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, 2016</ref> The population increase in the bay [[drainage basin|watershed]], from 3.7 million people in 1940 to 18 million in 2015 is also a major factor,<ref name=Miller/> as economic growth leads to the increased use of fertilizers and rising emissions of industrial waste.<ref>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/massive-nitrogen-pollution-accompanies-chinas-growth/ "Massive Nitrogen Pollution Accompanies China's Growth"], ''Scientific American'', Feb. 27, 2013</ref><ref>[http://e360.yale.edu/feature/on_lake_taihu_china_moves_to_battle_massive_algae_blooms/2429/ "On Lake Taihu, China Moves To Battle Massive Algae Blooms"], ''Environment 360'', Yale University, July 21, 2011</ref>
As of 2015, the six states and the local governments in the Chesapeake watershed have upgraded their sewage treatment plants to control nutrient discharges. The [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) estimates that sewage treatment plant improvements in the Chesapeake region between 1985 and 2015 have prevented the discharge of 900 million pounds (410 Gg) of nutrients, with nitrogen discharges reduced by 57% and phosphorus by 75%.<ref name="EPA-Chesapeake Pollution">{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/chesapeake-bay-tmdl/wastewater-pollution-reduction-chesapeake-bay-watershed |title=Wastewater Pollution Reduction in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-07-27 |publisher=EPA}}</ref> Agricultural and urban runoff pollution continue to be major sources of nutrients in the bay, and efforts to manage those problems are continuing throughout the {{convert|64000|sqmi|km2}} watershed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/chesapeake-bay-tmdl/chesapeake-bay-tmdl-fact-sheet |title=Chesapeake Bay TMDL Fact Sheet |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-09-29 |publisher=EPA}}</ref>
====Lake Erie==== Recent algae blooms in Lake Erie have been fed primarily by agricultural runoff and have led to warnings for some people in Canada and Ohio not to drink their water.<ref>https://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2014/08/toledo_water_crisis_must_spark.html</ref><ref>https://www.mlive.com/environment/index.ssf/2014/10/toxic_lake_erie_algal_blooms_r.html</ref> The International Joint Commission has called on United States and Canada to drastically reduce phosphorus loads into Lake Erie to address the threat.<ref>http://www.ijc.org/en_/leep/report</ref><ref>https://www.circleofblue.org/2014/world/joint-u-s-canada-agency-calls-big-phosphorus-reductions-lake-erie/</ref>
====Green Bay==== Green Bay has a dead zone caused by phosphorus pollution that appears to be getting worse.<ref>https://www.twincities.com/2013/08/15/scientists-dead-zone-showing-up-in-waters-of-green-bay/</ref>
==== Okeechobee Waterway ==== [[File:Cropped lake okeechobee oli 2016184 lrg.jpg|thumb|2016 [[NASA]] imagery showing an [[algal bloom]] on [[Lake Okeechobee]]. ]] [[Lake Okeechobee]] is an ideal habitat for cyanobacteria because it's shallow, sunny, and laden with nutrients from Florida's agriculture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Havens|first=Karl|last2=Li|first2=Bai-Lian|last3=Philips|first3=Edward|date=May 1998|title=Light availability as a possible regulator of cyanobacteria species composition in a shallow subtropical lake|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Edward_Phlips/publication/249440655_Light_availability_as_a_possible_regulator_of_cyanobacteria_species_composition_in_a_shallow_subtropical_lake/links/59dcace1aca2728e201f979d/Light-availability-as-a-possible-regulator-of-cyanobacteria-species-composition-in-a-shallow-subtropical-lake.pdf|journal=Freshwater Biology|volume=39|pages=547-556|via=Researchgate}}</ref> The [[Okeechobee Waterway]] connects the lake to the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and the [[Gulf of Mexico]] through the [[St. Lucie River]] and the [[Caloosahatchee River|Caloosahatchee]] respectively. This means that harmful algal blooms are carried down the estuaries as water is released during the wet summer months. In July 2018 up to 90% of Lake Okeechobee was covered in algae.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/09/us/algae-blooms-florida-nyt.html|title=Algae bloom in florida prompts fears about harm to health and economy|last=Gomez|first=Melissa|date=9 July 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref> Water draining from the lake filled the region with a noxious odor and caused respiratory problems in some humans during the following month.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.climate.gov/news-features/event-tracker/harmful-algal-blooms-linger-parts-southern-florida-july-and-august-2018|title=Harmful algal blooms linger in parts of southern Florida in July and August 2018|last=Di Liberto|first=Tom|date=16 August 2018|website=NOAA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref> To make matters worse, harmful red tide blooms are historically common on Florida's coasts during these same summer months.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Alcock|first=Frank|date=August 2007|title=An assessment of Florida red tide: causes, consequences, and management strategies.|url=https://dspace.mote.org/bitstream/2075/2911/1/Alcock-MPI_RedTide.pdf|journal=Mote Marine Technical Report|volume=1190|pages=|via=Mote Marine Laboratory}}</ref> Cyanobacteria in the rivers die as they reach saltwater but their nitrogen fixation feeds the red tide on the coast.<ref name=":1" /> Areas at the mouth of the estuaries such as [[Cape Coral, Florida|Cape Coral]] and [[Port St. Lucie, Florida|Port St. Lucie]] therefore experience the compounded effects of both types of harmful algal bloom. Cleanup crews hired by authorities in [[Lee County, Florida|Lee County]] - where the Caloosahatchee meets the Gulf of Mexico - removed more than 1700 tons of dead marine life in August 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/22/us/red-tide-fishkill-costs-trnd/index.html|title=Florida's red tide has produced 2,000 tons of dead marine life and cost businesses more than $8 million|last=Murphy|first=Paul|date=23 August 2018|work=CNN|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref>
====Coastal seas of Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan==== [[Open defecation]] is common in south Asia, but human waste is an often overlooked source of nutrient pollution in marine pollution modeling. When nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) contributed by human waste was included in models for Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan, the estimated N and P inputs to bodies of water increased one to two orders of magnitude compared to previous models.<ref name=":0" /> River export of nutrients to coastal seas increases coastal [[eutrophication]] potential (ICEP). The ICEP of the [[Godavari River]] is three times higher when N and P inputs from human waste are included.
==Harmful effects== As algal blooms grow, they deplete the oxygen in the water and block sunlight from reaching fish and plants. Such blooms can last from a few days to many months.<ref name=Utah2/> With less light, plants beneath the bloom can die and fish can starve.Furthermore, the dense population of a bloom reduces oxygen saturation during the night by respiration. And when the algae eventually die off, the microbes which decompose the dead algae use up even more oxygen, which in turn causes more fish to die or leave the area. When oxygen continues to be depleted by blooms it can lead to [[Hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxic]] [[dead zone (ecology)|dead zones]], where neither fish nor plants are able to survive.<ref>[http://science.sciencemag.org/content/321/5891/926 "Spreading Dead Zones and Consequences for Marine Ecosystems"], ''Science'', August 15, 2008</ref> These dead zones in the case of the Chesapeake Bay, where they are a normal occurrence, are also suspected of being a major source of [[methane]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Dietrich |first=Tamara |date=2016-07-19 |title=Study: Chesapeake Bay a bigger methane generator than previously thought |url=http://www.dailypress.com/news/science/dp-nws-chesapeake-bay-methane-20160719-story.html |work=Daily Press |location=Newport News, VA}}</ref>
The negative impact on fish can be even more severe when they are confined to pens, as they are in fish farms. In 2007 a fish farm in [[British Columbia]] lost 260 tons of salmon as a result of blooms,<ref>[http://www.farmedanddangerous.org/salmon-farming-problems/environmental-impacts/algae-blooms/ Algae Blooms in fish farming], Farmed and Dangerous.org</ref> and in 2016 a farm in Chile lost 23 million salmon after an algal bloom.<ref>[http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/03/10/3758642/chile-algal-bloom-salmon/ "One Of The U.S.’s Top Salmon Providers Just Lost Millions Of Salmon"], ''Climate Progress'', March 10, 2016</ref>
According to NOAA, less than one percent of algal blooms produce hazardous toxins, such as [[microcystins]].<ref name=NOAA>[http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/habharm.html "Are all algal blooms harmful?"], ''NOAA'', April 28, 2016</ref> Although blue-green or other algae do not usually pose a direct threat to health, the [[toxins]] (poisons) which they produce are considered dangerous to humans, land animals, sea mammals, birds<ref name=Utah2/> and fish when the toxins are ingested.<ref name=NOAA/> The toxins are [[neurotoxins]] which destroy nerve tissue which can affect the nervous system, brain, and liver, and can lead to death.<ref name=Utah/> Tests have shown some toxins near blooms can be in the air and thereby be inhaled, which could affect health.<ref>[https://weather.com/science/environment/news/florida-martin-county-algae-toxic-air-particles-marina-rio "Tests Reveal Florida's Toxic Algae is Threatening Not Only The Water Quality but Also the Air"], ''Weather.com'', July 28, 2016</ref>
There is no treatment available for animals, including livestock cattle, if they drink from algal blooms where such toxins are present. The Florida Department of Health recommends that people and pets be kept away from algal blooms to avoid contact.<ref>[http://www.marysvilleonline.net/news/article_49f895a6-4932-11e6-84b9-87884f9cfc1a.html?mode=print "Blue algae problems persist"], ''Marysville Online'', July 13, 2016</ref>
===Human health=== ====Food==== Eating fish or shellfish from lakes with a bloom nearby is not recommended.<ref name=California/> A study has shown that algal toxins may be the cause for as many as 60,000 intoxication cases in the world each year.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Hoagland P., Anderson D.M., Kaoru Y., White A.W.|first=|date=August 2002|title=The Economic Effects of Harmful Algal Blooms in the United States: Estimates, Assessment Issues, and Information Needs|journal=Estuaries|volume=4b|pages=819|jstor=258443}}</ref> This is due to the accumulation of potent toxins in shellfish that consume those algae and then these shellfish are later consumed by humans which may result in [[Amnesic shellfish poisoning]], [[Diarrhetic shellfish poisoning]], [[Neurotoxic shellfish poisoning]], and [[Paralytic shellfish poisoning]].<ref name=":02" /> Toxic [[paralytic shellfish poisoning]] in the [[Philippines]] during [[red tide]]s has caused at least 120 deaths over a few decades.<ref>[http://ojs.wpro.who.int/ojs/index.php/wpsar/article/view/302/485 "Lethal paralytic shellfish poisoning from consumption of green mussel broth, Western Samar, Philippines, August 2013"], ''World Health Organization'', Issue #2, April–June 2015</ref> After a HAB in [[Monterey Bay]], California, health officials warned people not to eat certain parts of anchovy, sardines, or crab caught in the bay.<ref name=KSBW>[http://www.ksbw.com/news/toxic-algae-blooms-killing-sea-birds-threaten-humans/25729808 "Toxic algae blooms killing sea birds, threaten humans"], ''KSBW'', April 30, 2014</ref> In 1987 a new illness emerged which was called [[amnesic shellfish poisoning]]. People who had eaten [[mussel]]s from [[Prince Edward Island]] were found to have [[amnesic shellfish poisoning]]. The illness was caused by domoic acid, produced by a diatom found in the area where the mussels were cultivated.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Backer |first=Lorraine C. |date=Fall 2017 |title=Harmful Algal Blooms. At the interface between coast oceanography and human health |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dennis_Mcgillicuddy/publication/276189630_Harmful_Algal_Blooms_At_the_Interface_Between_Coastal_Oceanography_and_Human_Health/links/558983b808ae273b2876c88c/Harmful-Algal-Blooms-At-the-Interface-Between-Coastal-Oceanography-and-Human-Health.pdf|journal=Oceanography |volume= 19 |issue=2 |page=96 |via=Researchgate.net}}</ref> In 2015 most shellfish fisheries in Washington, Oregon and California were shut down because of high concentrations of toxic domoic acid in shellfish.<ref name=shellfish/> People have been warned that inhaling vapors from waves or wind during a red tide may cause asthma attacks or lead to other respiratory ailments.<ref>{{cite journal |pmc= 2683400 |pmid=17218574 |doi=10.1378/chest.06-1830 |volume=131 |issue=1 |title=Aerosolized red-tide toxins (brevetoxins) and asthma | journal=Chest |pages=187–94 |author=Fleming LE, Kirkpatrick B, Backer LC, Bean JA, Wanner A, Reich A, Zaias J, Cheng YS, Pierce R, Naar J, Abraham WM, Baden DG|year=2007 }}</ref>
Agricultural officials in [[Utah]] worried that even crops could become contaminated if irrigated with toxic water, although they admit that they can't measure contamination accurately because of so many variables in farming. They issued warnings to residents, however, out of caution.<ref name=KSL>[https://www.ksl.com/?sid=40725118&nid=148 "Effects of algal blooms continue to spread throughout Wasatch Front"], ''KSL TV'', July 19, 2016</ref>
====Drinking water==== [[File:Toxic Algae Bloom in Lake Erie.jpg|thumb|px240|Satellite image of Lake Erie during an algal bloom in 2011]] Persons are generally warned not to enter or drink water from algal blooms, or let their pets swim in the water since many pets have died from algal blooms.<ref name=Russian/> In at least one case, people began getting sick before warnings were issued.<ref>[http://www.sgvtribune.com/environment-and-nature/20160718/people-got-sick-at-pyramid-lake-before-the-state-reported-toxic-algae-bloom-could-it-have-been-avoided "People got sick at Pyramid Lake before the state reported toxic algae bloom. Could it have been avoided?"], ''San Gabriel Valley Tribune'', July 18, 2016</ref>
In some locations visitors have been warned not to even touch the water.<ref name=California/> Boaters have been told that toxins in the water can be inhaled from the spray from wind or waves.<ref name=Peebles/><ref name=California/> Ocean beaches,<ref name=Florida/> lakes<ref name=Utah/> and rivers have been closed due to algal blooms.<ref name=Utah2>[http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/utah-county-portion-of-jordan-river-closed-due-to-toxic/article_3a5a7e25-504c-5821-b9c8-ce288f5c4e5e.html "Utah County portion of Jordan River closed due to toxic algal bloom"], ''Daily Herald'', July 21, 2016</ref> After a dog died in 2015 from swimming in a bloom in California's [[Russian River (California)|Russian River]], officials likewise posted warnings for parts of the river.<ref>[http://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/4425912-181/dog-dies-in-russian-river?artslide=0 "Dog dies on Russian River, tests positive for toxic algae"], Sept. 3, 2015</ref> Boiling the water at home before drinking does not remove the toxins.<ref name=California/>
Scientists in Britain, which has seen a huge increase in toxic algae, suspect that drinking water from sources that have blue-green algae may contribute to [[Alzheimer’s]], [[Parkinson’s]] or [[Lou Gehrig’s Disease]]. Few water treatment plants regularly test for [[cyanobacteria]]l toxins, however.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/science/science-news/11438278/British-lakes-see-huge-rise-in-toxic-algae-linked-to-Alzheimers.html "Drinking water could be poisoned with toxic algae linked to Alzheimer’s"], ''The Telegraph'', Feb. 26, 2015</ref>
In August 2014 the city of [[Toledo, Ohio]] advised its 500,000 residents to not drink tap water as the high toxin level from an algal bloom in western [[Lake Erie]] had affected their water treatment plant's ability to treat the water to a safe level.<ref name=Toledo>[http://www.ecowatch.com/toxic-algae-bloom-leaves-500-000-without-drinking-water-in-ohio-1881940537.html "Toxic Algae Bloom Leaves 500,000 Without Drinking Water in Ohio"], ''Ecowatch'', August 3, 2014</ref> The emergency required using bottled water for all normal uses except showering, which seriously affected public services and commercial businesses. The bloom returned in 2015<ref>[https://www.motherjones.com/tom-philpott/2015/08/giant-toxic-algae-bloom-haunts-toledo "The Big-Ag-Fueled Algae Bloom That Won't Leave Toledo's Water Supply Alone"], ''Mother Jones'', August 5, 2016</ref> and was forecast again for the summer of 2016.<ref>[http://www.ecowatch.com/lake-eries-toxic-algae-bloom-forecast-for-summer-2016-1891172391.html "Lake Erie’s Toxic Algae Bloom Forecast for Summer 2016"], ''EcoWatch'', June 13, 2016</ref>
In 2004, a bloom in Kisumu Bay, which is the drinking water source for 500,000 people in [[Kisumu]], [[Kenya]], suffered from similar water contamination.<ref name=Circle>[http://www.circleofblue.org/2014/world/draft-world-stands-algae-dead-zones-ruin-water/ "World Stands By As Algae and Dead Zones Ruin Water"], ''Circle of Blue'', Sept. 25, 2014</ref> In China, water was cut off to residents in 2007 due to an algal bloom in its third largest lake, which forced 2 million people to use bottled water.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/18959222/ns/world_news-world_environment/t/algae-smother-chinese-lake-millions-panic/#.V5fKbfkrLcs "Algae smother Chinese lake, millions panic"], NBC News, May 31, 2007</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Kahn |first=Joseph |date=2007-10-14 |title=In China, a Lake’s Champion Imperils Himself |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/14/world/asia/14china.html?_r=0 | work=New York Times}}</ref> A smaller water shut-down in China affected 15,000 residents two years later at a different location.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/08/content_11847923.htm "Algal bloom in Central China reservoir affects drinking water of 15,000"], ''Chinaview'', July 8, 2009</ref> Australia in 2016 also had to cut off water to farmers.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/bluegreen-algal-bloom-chokes-murray-cuts-water-to-farmers-20160308-gndihv.html "Blue-green algal bloom chokes Murray, cuts water to farmers"], ''The Age'', March 9, 2016</ref>
Alan Steinman of [[Grand Valley State University]] has explained that among the major causes for the algal blooms in general, and Lake Erie specifically, is because blue-green algae thrive with high nutrients, along with warm and calm water. Lake Erie is more prone to blooms because it has a high nutrient level and is shallow, which causes it to warm up more quickly during the summer.<ref>Video interview: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E2PsjhiZl2Q&t=38s Dr. Alan Steinman on Algal Blooms in Lake Erie] 13 min.</ref>
Symptoms from drinking toxic water can show up within a few hours after exposure. They can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, or trigger headaches and gastrointestinal problems.<ref name=Utah/> Although rare, liver toxicity can cause death.<ref name=Utah/> Those symptoms can then lead to dehydration, another major concern. In high concentrations, the toxins in the algal waters when simply touched can cause skin rashes, irritate the eyes, nose, mouth or throat.<ref name=California/> Those with suspected symptoms are told to call a doctor if symptoms persist or they can't hold down fluids after 24 hours.
===Economic impact=== ====Recreation and tourism==== The hazards which accompany harmful algal blooms have hindered visitors' enjoyment of beaches and lakes in places in the U.S. such as Florida,<ref name=Florida>[http://wlrn.org/post/summer-heat-could-worsen-algae-blooms-florida-waters "Summer Heat Could Worsen Algae Blooms In Florida Waters"], ''WLRN'', July 14, 2016</ref> California<ref name=California>[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-pyramid-lake-algae-bloom-20160714-snap-story.html "Summer conditions growing toxic algae blooms in two California lakes"], ''Los Angeles Times'', July 21, 2016</ref> Vermont,<ref>[http://www.necn.com/news/new-england/Vt-Beaches-Reopen-After-Algae-Blooms-Clear-386953991.html "Vt. Beaches Reopen After Algae Blooms Clear"], ''NECN'', July 15, 2016</ref> and Utah.<ref name="Utah2" /> Persons hoping to enjoy their vacations or days off have been kept away to the detriment of local economies. Lakes and rivers in [[North Dakota]], [[Minnesota]], Utah, California and Ohio have had signs posted warning about the potential of health risk.<ref>[http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/local/environment/2016/07/22/algae-blooming-waterways-all-around-country/87262178/ "Algae is blooming in waterways all around the country"], ''Florida Today'', July 22, 2016</ref>
In July 2016 [[Florida]] declared a [[state of emergency]] for four counties as a result of blooms. They were said to be "destroying" a number of businesses and affecting local economies, with many needing to shut down entirely.<ref>[http://www.natureworldnews.com/articles/25512/20160719/look-florida-toxic-algae-choking-economy-environment.htm "How Florida's Toxic Algae is Choking the Economy And The Environment"], ''Nature World News'', July 19, 2016</ref> Some beaches were closed, and hotels and restaurants suffered a drop in business. Tourist sporting activities such as fishing and boating were also affected.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/business/consumer/florida-tourism-not-seeing-green-toxic-algae-chokes-business-n607106 "Florida Tourism Not Seeing Green as Toxic Algae Chokes Business"], ''NBC News'', July 11, 2016</ref><ref name=Florida2>[https://www.cnbc.com/2016/07/05/toxic-algae-driving-away-florida-beachgoers.html "Toxic algae driving away Florida beachgoers"], ''CNBC'', July 5, 2016</ref> Senator [[Marco Rubio]] called the situation in Florida "a health, ecological and economic emergency."<ref name=Huffington>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/florida-algal-blooms_us_577d70cee4b0c590f7e7e3d2 "Toxic Algal Blooms Aren’t Just Florida’s Problem. And They’re On The Rise."], ''Huffington Post'', July 7, 2016</ref>
[[File:Negotiating algae one stroke at a time (15010363755).jpg|thumb|px240|Boaters in a freshwater algal bloom]] Similar blooms have become more common in Europe, with France among the countries reporting them. In the summer of 2009, beaches in northern [[Brittany]] became covered by tonnes of potentially lethal rotting green algae. A horse being ridden along the beach collapsed and died from fumes given off by the rotting algae.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/10/france-brittany-coast-seaweed-algae "Lethal algae take over beaches in northern France"], ''The Guardian'', U.K., August 10, 2009</ref>
The economic damage resulting from lost business has become a serious concern. According to one report in 2016, the four main economic impacts from harmful algal blooms come from damage to human health, fisheries, tourism and recreation, and the cost of monitoring and management of area where blooms appear.<ref name=JRC/> EPA estimates that algal blooms impact 65 percent of the country's major estuaries, with an annual cost of $2.2 billion.<ref name=KSL/> In the U.S. there are an estimated 166 coastal dead zones.<ref name=KSL/> Because data collection has been more difficult and limited from sources outside the U.S., most of the estimates as of 2016 have been primarily for the U.S.<ref name=JRC>[https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/publication/algal-bloom-and-its-economic-impact "Algal bloom and its economic impact"], ''European Commission Joint Research Centre'', 2016</ref>
In port cities in the [[Shandong Province]] of eastern China, residents are no longer surprised when massive algal blooms arrive each year and inundate beaches. Prior to the Beijing Olympics in 2008, over 10,000 people worked to clear 20,000 tons of dead algae from beaches.<ref name=China>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/china-yellow-sea-turns-green-qingdao-beaches-are-covered-algae-photos-1509734 "China: Yellow Sea turns green as Qingdao beaches are covered in algae"], ''International Business Times'', July 7, 2015</ref> In 2013 another bloom in China, thought to be its largest ever,<ref>[http://phys.org/news/2013-07-china-largest-ever-algae-bloom.html "China hit by largest-ever algae bloom"], ''Phys.org'', July 4, 2013</ref> covered an area of 7,500 square miles,<ref name=China/> and was followed by another in 2015 which blanketed an even greater 13,500 square miles. The blooms in China are thought to be caused by pollution from untreated agricultural and industrial discharges into rivers leading to the ocean.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com/china-has-an-algae-beach-pollution-problem-2015-7?r=UK&IR=T "Slimy green algae is taking over China's beaches for an alarming reason"], ''Business Insider'', July 13, 2015</ref>
====Fisheries industry==== [[File:NOAA Pacific coast 2015.jpg|thumb|px240|West coast algal bloom of 2015 which led to closing of fisheries]] As early as 1976 a short-term, relatively small, dead zone off the coasts of [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[New Jersey]] cost commercial and recreational fisheries over $500 million.<ref name=SciAm2/> In 1998 a red tide in Hong Kong killed over $10 million in high-value fish.<ref name=Brown/>
In 2009, the economic impact for the state of [[Washington (state)|Washington's]] coastal counties dependent on its fishing industry was estimated to be $22 million.<ref>{{cite news |last=Miner |first=Colin |date=2009-11-27 |title=Assessing Algal Blooms’ Economic Impact |url=https://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/27/assessing-algal-blooms-economic-impact/ |work=New York Times |series=Green: Energy, the Environment and the Bottom Line (blog)}}</ref> In 2016, the U.S. seafood industry expected future lost revenue could amount to $900 million annually.<ref name=JRC/>
NOAA has provided a few cost estimates for various blooms over the past few years:<ref name=NOAA3>{{cite web |url=http://www.noaa.gov/what-is-harmful-algal-bloom |title=What is a harmful algal bloom? |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-04-27 |website= |publisher=U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> $10.3 million in 2011 due to the red tide at Texas oyster landings; $2.4 million lost income by tribal commerce from 2015 fishery closures in the pacific northwest; $40 million from Washington state's loss of tourism from the same fishery closure.
Along with damage to businesses, the toll from human sickness results in lost wages and damaged health. The costs of medical treatment, investigation by health agencies through water sampling and testing, and the posting of warning signs at effected locations is also costly.<ref name=WHOI>[https://www.whoi.edu/fileserver.do?id=24159&pt=10&p=19132 "Estimated Annual Economic Impacts from Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs) in the United States"], Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, September 2000</ref>
The closures applied to areas where this algae bloom occurs has a big negative impact of the fishing industries, add to that the high fish mortality that follows, the increase in price due to the shortage of fish available and decrease in the demand for seafood due to the fear of contamination by toxins.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Algae bloom and its economic impact |last=Sanseverino |first=Isabella |publisher=JRC publications |year=2016 |isbn=978-92-79-58101-4 |location=Europe |pages=23, 26, 27}}</ref> This causes a big economic loss for the industry.
Economic costs are estimated to rise. In June 2015, for instance, the largest known toxic HAB forced the shutdown of the west coast shellfish industry, the first time that has ever happened. One Seattle NOAA expert commented, "This is unprecedented in terms of the extent and magnitude of this harmful algal bloom and the warm water conditions we're seeing offshore...."<ref name=Oregon>[http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2015/06/west_coast_shellfish_industrie.html "Biggest-ever toxic algal bloom hits West Coast, shutting down shellfish industries"], ''Oregon Live'', June 16, 2015</ref> The bloom covered a range from [[Santa Barbara, California]] northward to [[Alaska]].<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/toxic-algae-bloom-in-pacific-ocean-could-be-largest-ever/ "Toxic algae bloom in Pacific Ocean could be largest ever"], ''CBS News'', June 17, 2015</ref>
===Environmental impact=== [[File:Dead-Zone - Gulf-of-Mexico.jpg|thumb|px240|Portion of a dead zone in the [[Gulf of Mexico]]]]
====Increasing number and range==== The number of reported harmful algal blooms (cyanobacterial) has been increasing throughout the world.<ref name=usgs2>{{cite report |editor-last1=Friend |editor-first1=Milton |editor-last2=Franson |editor-first2=J. Christian |date=1999 |title=Field Manual of Wildlife Diseases |chapter=Ch. 36. Algal toxins |page=263 |url=http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/publications/field_manual/chapter_36.pdf |publisher=National Wildlife Health Center, United States Geological Survey (USGS) |location=Madison, WI |id=1999-001 |isbn=0-607-88096-1}}</ref> In the U.S., every coastal state has had harmful algal blooms over the last decade, and species have emerged in new locations that were not previously known to have problems.<ref name=NOAA4>{{cite web |url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories2015/091715-noaa-awards-2.1-million-to-improve-observation-forecasting-and-mitigation-of-harmful-algal-blooms-and-hypoxia.html |title=NOAA awards $2.1 million to improve observation, forecasting, and mitigation of harmful algal blooms and hypoxia |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2015-09-17 |website= |publisher=NOAA}}</ref> Inland, major rivers have seen an increase in their size and frequency. In 2015 the [[Ohio River]] had a bloom which stretched an "unprecedented" {{convert|650|mi|km}} into adjoining states and tested positive for toxins, which created drinking water and recreation problems.<ref>[http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2015/10/03/algae-along-the-ohio.html "Toxic algae bloom now stretches 650 miles along Ohio river"], ''The Columbus Dispatch'', Oct. 3, 2015</ref> A portion of Utah's [[Jordan River (Utah)|Jordan River]] was closed due to toxic algal bloom in 2016.<ref name=Utah2/>
Researchers have reported the growth of HABs in Europe, Africa and Australia. Those have included blooms on some of the [[African Great Lakes]], such as [[Lake Victoria]], the second largest freshwater lake in the world.<ref name=Circle/> [[India]] has been reporting an increase in the number of blooms each year.<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/boom-in-harmful-algal-blooms/article963739.ece "Boom in harmful algal blooms"], ''The Hindu'', Dec 20, 2010</ref> In 1977 [[Hong Kong]] reported its first red tide. By 1987 they were getting an average of 35 per year.<ref name=Brown>Brown, Lester; McGinn, Anne Platt. ''Vital Signs 1999–2000: The Environmental Trends that Are Shaping Our Future'', Routledge (1999 pp. 198–199</ref> Additionally, there have been reports of harmful algal blooms throughout popular Canadian lakes such as Beaver Lake and Quamichan Lake. These blooms were responsible for the deaths of a few animals and led to swimming advisories.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/blue-green-algae-beaver-lake-1.4214729|title=Toxic blue-green algae ends swimming at popular Victoria lake|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en}}</ref>
Global warming and pollution is causing algal blooms to form in places previously considered "impossible" or rare for them to exist, such as under the ice sheets in the [[Arctic]],<ref>[http://news.stanford.edu/news/2012/june/arctic-algal-blooms-060712.html "NASA mission, led by Stanford biologist, finds massive algal blooms under Arctic sea ice"], ''Stanford News'', June 7, 2012</ref> in [[Antarctica]],<ref>[http://www.livescience.com/18915-antarctic-algae-bloom-nasa.html "Behemoth Antarctic Algae Bloom Seen from Space"], ''Life Science'', March 7, 2012</ref> the [[Himalayan Mountains]],<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/environment/pollution-neglect-and-too-much-love-killing-once-idyllic-himalayan-lake-20111104-1mzw0.html "Pollution, neglect and too much love killing once idyllic Himalayan lake"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', Nov. 5, 2011</ref> the [[Rocky Mountains]],<ref>[http://jordanramis.com/water-law-blog/addressing-algal-blooms-in-rocky-mountain-national-park/ "Addressing Algal Blooms in Rocky Mountain National Park"], Jordan Ramis, August 6, 2015</ref> and in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada Mountains]].<ref>[https://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/emergency/wilderness/Sierra_Algae-pdf10-14-09.pdf " Algae in Sierra Nevada Mountain Wilderness Areas: Potential Health Hazards"], ''Journal of Mountain Medicine and Ecology'', University of California, Davis, Fall 2009</ref>
====Fish die-offs==== [[File:Atibaia 2014-02-19 - Seca no Rio Atibaia (3) (13587504875).jpg|thumb|px240|Massive fish die-off in Brazil]] Massive fish die-offs have been caused by HABs.<ref name=WHOI-2>[https://www.whoi.edu/science/B/redtide/foodweb/fishkills.html "Fish Kills due to Harmful Algal Blooms"], ''Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute</ref> In 2016, 23 million salmon which were being farmed in Chile died from a toxic algae bloom.<ref name=salmon>[http://www.ecowatch.com/23-million-salmon-dead-due-to-toxic-algal-bloom-in-chile-1882188276.html "23 Million Salmon Dead Due to Toxic Algal Bloom in Chile"], ''EcoWatch'', March 10, 2016</ref> To get rid of the dead fish, the ones fit for consumption were made into fishmeal and the rest were dumped 60 miles offshore to avoid risks to human health.<ref name=salmon/> The economic cost of that die-off is estimated to have been $800 million.<ref name=salmon/> Environmental expert [[Lester Brown]] has written that the farming of salmon and shrimp in offshore ponds concentrates waste, which contributes to [[eutrophication]] and the creation of dead zones.<ref>Brown, Lester R. [http://www.earth-policy.org/images/uploads/book_files/pb4book.pdf ''Plan B 4.0: Mobilizing to Save Civilization''], Earth Policy Institute, p. 227</ref>
Other countries have reported similar impacts, with cities such as [[Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil seeing major fish die-offs from blooms becoming a common occurrence.<ref name=Brazil>[http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/21/brazil-removes-50-tons-of-dead-fish-from-olympic-waters.html "Brazil removes 50 tons of dead fish from Olympic waters"], ''Aljazeera'', April 21, 2015</ref> In early 2015, Rio collected an estimated 50 tons of dead fish from the lagoon where water events in the 2016 Olympics were planned to take place.<ref name=Brazil/>
The [[Monterey Bay]] has suffered from harmful algal blooms, most recently in 2015: "Periodic blooms of toxin-producing ''[[Pseudo-nitzschia]]'' diatoms have been documented for over 25 years in Monterey Bay and elsewhere along the U.S. west coast. During large blooms, the [[Bioaccumulation|toxin accumulates]] in shellfish and small fish such as anchovies and sardines that feed on algae, forcing the closure of some fisheries and poisoning marine mammals and birds that feed on contaminated fish."<ref>Tim Stephens, [http://news.ucsc.edu/2015/05/algal-bloom.html Large bloom of toxic algae under way in Monterey Bay and beyond], [[UC Santa Cruz]] (June 2, 2015).</ref> Similar fish die-offs from toxic algae or lack of oxygen have been seen in Russia,<ref>[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fsobitie.com.ua%2Fnovosti%2Fv-kamenskom-mestnye-vlasti-nanyali-podryadchikov-ubirat-gory-mertvoy-ryby-s-plyazhey&edit-text=&act=url "Kamensk local authorities have hired contractors to clean up mountains of dead fish from the beaches"], July 18, 2016</ref> Colombia,<ref>[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wradio.com.co%2Fnoticias%2Fregionales%2Freportan-mortandad-de-peces-en-los-palafitos%2F20160717%2Fnota%2F3191232.aspx&edit-text=&act=url "Fish kills reported in the Palafitos"], W Radio, July 17, 2016</ref> Vietnam,<ref>[http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/160721/thanh-hoa--locals-wear-masks-as-smell-from-dead-fish-overpowering.html "Thanh Hoa: Locals wear masks as smell from dead fish overpowering"], Vietnam.net, July 19, 2016</ref> China,<ref>[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fjs.ifeng.com%2Fa%2F20160706%2F4725768_0.shtml&edit-text=&act=url "Hongze Lake Suqian great, full of dead fish breeding area"], Modern Express Network, July 6, 2016</ref> Canada,<ref>[http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/environment/tens-of-thousands-of-fish-dead-in-quebec-s-yamaska-river/article/469215 "Massive fish kill in Quebec's Yamaska River puzzle scientists"], ''Digital Journal'', July 4, 2016</ref> Turkey,<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/scores-of-starfish-wash-ashore-in-turkeys-northwest.aspx?pageID=238&nID=101009&NewsCatID=341 "Scores of starfish wash ashore in Turkey’s northwest"], ''Hurriyet Daily News'', June 28, 2016</ref> Indonesia,<ref>[http://www.radarcirebon.com/90-ton-ikan-waduk-darma-mati-masal-ini-penyebabnya.html "90 Tons of Fish Die Darma Masal"], Radar Cirebon, June 2, 2016</ref> and France.<ref>[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.francetvinfo.fr%2Fmeteo%2Fmaine-et-loire-des-milliers-de-poissons-asphyxies-avec-la-decrue_1506061.html%23xtor%3DAL-67-&edit-text=&act=url "Maine-et-Loire: Thousands of fish suffocated with the decline"], ''France TV'', June 18, 2016</ref>
====Land animal deaths==== Land animals, including livestock and pets have been affected. Dogs have died from the toxins after swimming in algal blooms.<ref>[http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2015/02/02/3617937/california-algae-bloom/ "Unseasonal Toxic Algae Bloom In California Lake Kills Three Dogs"], ''Climate Progress'', Feb. 2, 2015</ref> Warnings have come from government agencies in the state of Ohio, which noted that many dogs and livestock deaths resulted from HAB exposure in the U.S. and other countries. They also noted in a 2003 report that during the previous 30 years, they have seen more frequent and longer-lasting harmful algal blooms."<ref name=Ohio>[http://epa.ohio.gov/portals/35/inland_lakes/OhioVeterinaryAssociationArticle40910%20.pdf "Harmful Algal Blooms Can Be Deadly to Pets and Livestock"], ''Ohio Environmental Protection Agency''</ref> In 50 countries and 27 states that year there were reports of human and animal illnesses linked to algal toxins.<ref name=Ohio/> In Australia, the department of agriculture warned farmers that the toxins from a HAB had the "potential to kill large numbers of livestock very quickly."<ref>[http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal-poisoning-of-stock "Blue-green algal poisoning of stock"], ''Agriculture Victoria''</ref>
[[File:Dead whale NOAA.jpg|thumb|left|px240|Dead whale from an algal bloom]] Marine mammals have also been seriously harmed, as over 50 percent of unusual marine mammal deaths are caused by harmful algal blooms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://celebrating200years.noaa.gov/foundations/coastal_research/dead_whale_500.html |title=Over 50 percent of unusual marine mammal mortality events are caused by harmful algal blooms. |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2007-02-13 |website=Coastal Ecosystem Research |publisher=NOAA}}</ref> In 1999, over 65 [[bottlenose dolphins]] died during a red tide in Florida.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/websites/retiredsites/sotc_pdf/hab.pdf |title=Harmful Algal Blooms |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2000-02-15 |website=State of the Coastal Environment |publisher=NOAA}}</ref> In 2013 a [[red tide]] in southwest Florida killed a record number of [[Manatee]].<ref>[http://www.accuweather.com/en/outdoor-articles/beach-marine/red-tide-algae-bloom-kills-rec/8049099 "Red Tide Algae Bloom Kills Record Number of Manatee"], ''Accuweather'', March 13, 2013</ref> Whales have also died in large numbers. During the period from 2005 to 2014, Argentina reported an average 65 baby whales dying which experts have linked to algal blooms. A whale expert there expects the whale population to be reduced significantly.<ref>[http://www.ecowatch.com/algal-blooms-linked-to-largest-die-off-of-great-whales-ever-recorded-1882115945.html "Algal Blooms Linked to Largest Die-Off of Great Whales Ever Recorded"], ''EcoWatch'', Oct. 29, 2015</ref> In 2003 off [[Cape Cod]] in the North Atlantic, at least 12 humbpack whales died from toxic algae from a red tide.<ref>[http://www.nature.com/news/2003/030804/full/news030804-1.html "Toxic algae suspected in whale death"], ''Nature'', August 4, 2003</ref> In 2015 Alaska and British Columbia reported many [[humpback whales]] had likely died from HAB toxins, with 30 having washed ashore in Alaska. "Our leading theory at this point is that the harmful algal bloom has contributed to the deaths," said a NOAA spokesperson.<ref>[http://www.nigerian-news.com/30-dead-whales-wash-ashore-in-alaska-scientists-commence-investigations/ "30 Dead Whales Wash Ashore In Alaska; Scientists Commence Investigations"], ''Nigerian News'', August 24, 2015</ref><ref>[https://www.inverse.com/article/6223-toxic-algae-blooms-could-be-causing-whale-deaths "Toxic Algae Could Be Killing Dozens of Whales"], ''Inverse'', Sept. 16, 2015</ref>
Birds have died after eating dead fish contaminated with toxic algae. Rotting and decaying fish are eaten by birds such as [[pelicans]], [[seagulls]], [[cormorant]]s, and possibly marine or land mammals, which then become poisoned.<ref name=WHOI-2/> The nervous systems of dead birds were examined and had failed from the toxin's effect.<ref name=KSBW/> On the Oregon and Washington coast, a thousand [[scoter]]s, or sea ducks, were also killed in 2009. ""This is huge," said a University professor.<ref name=Oregon2>[http://www.oregonlive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/10/foam_from_ocean_algae_bloom_ki.html "Foam from ocean algae bloom killing thousands of birds"], ''Oregon Live'', October 22, 2009</ref> As dying or dead birds washed up on the shore, wildlife agencies went into "an emergency crisis mode."<ref name=Oregon2/>
It has even been suggested that harmful algal blooms are responsible for the deaths of animals found in fossil troves.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Gramling C. |year=2017 |title=Toxic algae may be culprit in mysterious dinosaur deaths |journal=Science |volume=357 |issue=6354 |page=857 |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/357/6354/857.1 |pmid=28860363 |doi=10.1126/science.357.6354.857-a}}</ref>
====More dead zones==== [[File:Gulf dead zone.jpg|thumb|px240|Dead zone in the southern U.S.]] According to NOAA, blooms can harm the environment even without producing toxins by depleting oxygen from the water when growing and while decaying after they die. Blooms can also block sunlight to organisms living beneath it. A record-breaking number and size of blooms have formed in the Pacific coast, in Lake Erie, in the Chesapeake Bay and in the Gulf of Mexico, where a number of dead zones were created as a result.<ref name=Huffington/> In the 1960s the number of dead zones worldwide was 49; the number rose to over 400 by 2008.<ref name=SciAm2>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/oceanic-dead-zones-spread/ "Oceanic Dead Zones Continue to Spread"], ''Scientific American'', August 15, 2008</ref> In the U.S. they are especially prevalent along the east and south coasts.<ref name=SciAm2/>
Various important natural habitats such as rivers, lakes and [[estuaries]] have continued to degrade and has contributed to creating more oxygen-deprived [[dead zone (ecology)|dead zones]], including some in the Gulf of Mexico, the Chesapeake Bay, and Lake Erie.<ref>[http://www.livescience.com/49347-lake-erie-dead-zone-drought.html "Lake Erie Dead Zone: Don't Blame the Slime!"], ''Live Science'', January 6, 2015</ref><ref name=Circle2>Kozacek, Codi. [http://www.circleofblue.org/2016/united-states/algal-blooms-no-accident-florida-everglades-estuaries/ "Algal Blooms Are No Accident For Florida Everglades and Estuaries"], ''Circle of Blue'', July 20, 2016</ref>
Among the largest dead zones were those in northern Europe’s [[Baltic Sea]] and the Gulf of Mexico, which affects a $2.8 billion U.S. fish industry.<ref name=Circle/> Unfortunately, dead zones rarely recover and usually grow in size.<ref name=SciAm2/> One of the few dead zones to ever recover was in the [[Black Sea]], which returned to normal fairly quickly after the collapse of the Soviet Union in the 1990s due to a resulting reduction in fertilizer use.<ref name=SciAm2/>
==Potential remedies== ===Chemical treatment and dams=== Although a number of [[algaecide]]s have been effective in killing algae, they have been used mostly in small bodies of water. For large algal blooms, however, adding algaecides such as silver nitrate or copper sulfate can have worse effects, such as killing fish outright and harming other wildlife.<ref name=Greensburg>[http://www.greensburgdailynews.com/news/local_news/what-is-creeping-into-our-lakes/article_d77a16fa-ef97-5f5c-bb18-ae7b1acca0fa.html "What is creeping into our lakes?"], ''Greensburg Daily News'', August 16, 2016</ref> The negative effects can therefore be worse than letting the algae die off naturally.<ref name=Greensburg/><ref name=OSU/>
Other experts have proposed building reservoirs to prevent the movement of algae downstream. However, that can lead to the growth of algae within the reservoir, which become sediment traps with a resultant buildup of nutrients.<ref name=Greensburg/> Some researchers found that intensive blooms in reservoirs were the primary source of toxic algae observed downstream, but the movement of algae has so far been less studied, although it is considered a likely cause of algae transport.<ref name=OSU>[http://oregonstate.edu/ua/ncs/archives/2015/jun/toxic-algal-blooms-behind-klamath-river-dams-create-health-risks-far-downstream "Toxic algal blooms behind Klamath River dams create health risks far downstream"], ''Oregon State University News'', June 16, 2015</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/nutrient-policy-data/control-and-treatment |title=Control and Treatment |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2017-03-02 |website=Nutrient Policy and Data |publisher=EPA}}</ref>
===Sensors and monitoring devices=== A growing number of scientists agree that there is an urgent need to protect the public by being able to forecast harmful algal blooms.<ref name="NYT-Richtel">{{cite news |last=Richtel |first=Matt |date=2016-07-18 |title=A Dreaded Forecast for Our Times: Algae, and Lots of It |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/19/science/a-dreaded-forecast-for-our-times-algae-and-lots-of-it.html?_r=1 |work=New York Times}}</ref> One way they hope to do that is with sophisticated sensors which can help warn about potential blooms.<ref>[http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/122-a206/ "Keeping Tabs on HABs: New Tools for Detecting, Monitoring, and Preventing Harmful Algal Blooms"], ''Environmental Health Perspectives'', August 1, 2014</ref> The same types of sensors can also be used by water treatment facilities to help them prepare for higher toxic levels.<ref name="NYT-Richtel"/><ref>[http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/122-a206/ "Keeping Tabs on HABs: New Tools for Detecting, Monitoring, and Preventing Harmful Algal Blooms"], ''Environmental Health Perspectives'', August 2014</ref>
The only sensors now in use are located in the Gulf of Mexico. In 2008 similar sensors in the Gulf forewarned of an increased level of toxins which led to a shutdown of shellfish harvesting in Texas along with a recall of mussels, clams and oysters, possibly saving many lives. With an increase in the size and frequency of HABs, experts state the need for significantly more sensors located around the country.<ref name="NYT-Richtel"/> The same kinds of sensors can also be used to detect threats to drinking water from intentional contamination.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/homeland-security-research/water-system-security-and-resilience-homeland-security-research |title=Water System Security and Resilience in Homeland Security Research |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-12-20 |publisher=EPA}}</ref>
Four U.S. federal agencies—EPA, the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA), NOAA, and the [[U.S. Geological Survey]] (USGS)—are working on ways to detect and measure cyanobacteria blooms using satellite data.<ref>[http://www.algaeindustrymagazine.com/us-agencies-creating-algal-bloom-early-warning-system/ "US agencies creating algal bloom early warning system"], ''Algae Industry Magazine'', April 8, 2015</ref> The data may help develop early-warning indicators of cyanobacteria blooms by monitoring both local and national coverage.<ref name=satellite>[http://toxics.usgs.gov/highlights/2015-12-21-cyanobacteria_sensing.html "Remote Sensing Provides a National View of Cyanobacteria Blooms"], USGS</ref> In 2016 automated early-warning monitoring systems were successfully tested, and for the first time proven to identify the rapid growth of algae and the subsequent depletion of oxygen in the water.<ref>[https://www.news.virginia.edu/content/scientists-develop-early-warning-system-toxic-algae-blooms "Scientists Develop Early-Warning System for Toxic Algae Blooms"], ''UVA Today'', Univ. of Virginia, Jan. 4, 2017</ref>
However, in the U.S. at least, funding for such warning devices has been shrinking, with approved funding down 45% over the last five years.{{When|date=August 2018}} According to one marine science professor, "We need it more than ever, and we’ve brought ourselves to the precipice of making great forecasts, but we can’t make it happen."<ref name="NYT-Richtel"/>
===Reducing chemical runoff=== [[File:Runoff of soil & fertilizer.jpg|thumb|px240|Soil and fertilizer runoff from a farm after heavy rains]] The nitrates and phosphorus in fertilizers cause algal blooms when they run off into lakes and rivers after heavy rains. Modifications in farming methods have been suggested, such as only using fertilizer in a targeted way at the appropriate time exactly where it can do the most good for crops to reduce potential runoff.<ref name=SciAm/> A method used successfully is [[drip irrigation]], which instead of widely dispersing fertilizers on fields, drip-irrigates plant roots through a network of tubes and emitters, leaving no traces of fertilizer to be washed away.<ref>Siegel, Seth M. ''Let There Be Water: Israel’s Solution for a Water-Starved World'', Macmillan (2015) p. 66</ref> According to the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD), drip irrigation also prevents the formation of algal blooms in [[reservoirs]] for drinking water<ref>[http://www.oecdobserver.org/news/fullstory.php/aid/4819/Israel:_Innovations_overcoming_water_scarcity.html "Israel: Innovations overcoming water scarcity"], ''OECD Observer'', April 2015</ref> while saving up to 50% of water typically used by agriculture.<ref>[http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/jun/16/israel-drought-water-reclamation/ "How Israel survived its devastating drought"], ''San Diego Union-Tribune'', June 16, 2015</ref>
A number of states in the U.S. have tried eliminating [[phosphates in detergent]] and by cleaning{{Vague|date=September 2017}} water treatment plants, which succeeded in reducing the amount that entered Lake Erie by 66%.{{Failed verification|date=September 2017 |reason=No mention of 'cleaned' plants reducing phosphorus in cited article}} However, changes in farming practices during that period increased chemical runoff, thereby offsetting the improvements.<ref name=SciAm>Biello, David. [http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/deadly-algae-are-everywhere-thanks-to-agriculture/ "Deadly Algae Are Everywhere, Thanks to Agriculture"], ''Scientific American'', August 8, 2014</ref>
There have also been proposals to create buffer zones of foliage and wetlands to help filter out the phosphorus before it reaches water.<ref name=SciAm/> Other experts have suggested using conservation tillage, changing crop rotations, and restoring wetlands.<ref name=SciAm/> "The most important thing that can be done is to reduce agricultural runoff," according to a Great Lakes pollution expert. "Prevention is better than treatment."<ref name=SciAm/> Another expert states that it is possible for some dead zones to shrink within a year under proper management.<ref name=Larsen/>
There have been a few success stories in controlling chemicals. After Norway's lobster fishery collapsed in 1986 due to low oxygen levels, for instance, the government in neighboring Denmark took action and reduced phosphorus output by 80 percent which brought oxygen levels closer to normal.<ref name=Larsen>Larsen, Janet. [http://www.earth-policy.org/plan_b_updates/2004/update41 "Dead Zones Increasing in the World's Coastal Waters"], Earth Policy Institute, June 16, 2004</ref> Similarly, dead zones in the [[Black Sea]] and along the [[Danube River]] recovered after phosphorus applications by farmers were reduced by 60%.<ref name=Larsen/>
===Research and management=== {{multiple image | image1 = Super Blooms.ogv | width1 = 300 | alt1 = | caption1 = Algal blooms forming and breaking up over time | direction = horizontal }}
In 2008, the U.S. government prepared a report on the problem, "Harmful Algal Bloom Management and Response: Assessment and Plan".<ref name=US>[https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/jsost_hab0908.pdf "Harmful Algal Bloom Management and Response: Assessment and Plan"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510152427/http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/jsost_hab0908.pdf |date=2013-05-10 }}, Office of Science and Technology Policy, Sept. 2008</ref> The change recognized the seriousness of the problem: {{quote|It is widely believed that the frequency and geographic distribution of HABs have been increasing worldwide. All U.S. coastal states have experienced HABs over the last decade, and new species have emerged in some locations that were not previously known to cause problems. HAB frequency is also thought to be increasing in freshwater systems.<ref name=US/>}} The report suggested among other remedies, using improved monitoring methods, trying to improve predictability, and testing new potential methods of controlling HABs.<ref name=US/> Some countries surrounding the Baltic Sea, which has the world's largest dead zone, have considered using massive geoengineering options, such as forcing air into bottom layers to aerate them.<ref name=SciAm2/>
In 2015, NOAA created 12 new research grants totaling nearly $2.1 million which they would award to national organizations doing research on harmful algal blooms and hypoxia, which they consider to be "two of the most scientifically complex and economically damaging coastal issues."<ref name=NOAA4/>
===Monitoring and reporting=== Most countries, states and large cities have departments which will help monitor and report incidents of algal blooms. The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) in the U.S. launched the country's first algal bloom reporting system in June 2016.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/a0622-algal-blooms.html "CDC launches first national reporting system for harmful algal blooms and associated illnesses"], CDC, June 22, 2016</ref> Environmental agencies in individual U.S. states will accept reports of blooms from citizens and will work with cities to test and report incidents to the media. A few examples: *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160808144007/http://www.who.int/water_sanitation_health/bathing/srwe1execsum/en/index6.html World Health Organization (WHO)] *[http://www.issha.org/Welcome-to-ISSHA/Harmful-Algae-Links/General-Information International Society for the Study of Harmful Algae (ISSHA)] *[http://www.dec.ny.gov/chemical/81962.html New York state] *[http://www.epa.illinois.gov/topics/water-quality/surface-water/algal-bloom/reporting/index Illinois] *[https://www.nwtoxicalgae.org/ Washington state] *[https://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/environhealth/water/Pages/Bluegreenalgae.aspx California] *[http://tpwd.texas.gov/landwater/water/environconcerns/hab/ Texas] *[http://www.dep.state.fl.us/water/bgalgae/ Florida]
==Notes== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
